sections.text:
Forecast numbers that don’t match manager intuition are currently a trust barrier: even when the model is right, managers can’t tell what changed or why. This leads to slower adoption, more time spent reconciling forecasts manually, and less willingness to use the forecast early in the cycle when it’s most valuable.

Adding an explainability panel that breaks the forecast into its key contributing signals (e.g., stage, recent activity, fit score, slippage risk) makes the output legible and defensible. Showing per-signal impact alongside “last updated” timestamps helps managers quickly validate whether a movement is driven by real pipeline changes or stale/missing inputs, reducing the need for ad-hoc investigation.

Consistency across account and opportunity views ensures the same narrative holds wherever managers work, avoiding confusion and “two truths” depending on the page. Using the exact same inputs as the forecasting model is critical to credibility—managers can trace the forecast back to the model’s drivers and confidently explain changes to leadership and reps.

Overall impact is increased early trust and faster decision-making: managers can spot what’s driving risk, coach reps on the highest-leverage actions, and intervene sooner on slipping deals. This should reduce forecast churn and escalation cycles, improving forecast adoption and the quality of pipeline conversations without requiring users to become model experts.
